But on rare occasions, her drawing would be taped to the inside of his door, or he'd emerge and ruffle her hair, a ghost of a smile on his face. In her seven-year-old heart, it was a victory. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

Eleonora was a ghost, tethered to the dusty silence of the old city archives. Simon was a doctoral student, slowly being crushed by the weight of his thesis. She watched him day after day, his shoulders slumping further, his face pale under the fluorescent lights. He was fading, just as she had. She couldn't speak, she couldn't touch him, but she could influence the world in small, quiet ways. A gentle, unseen push would send the perfect research volume tumbling from a high shelf into his path. When he’d sigh in frustration, she’d stir the air, creating a soft breeze that smelled of old paper and rain, a scent she knew from her own long-lost life was calming. Once, she managed to flicker the lights in time with a forgotten song playing faintly on his headphones. He looked up, bewildered, a flicker of curiosity in his tired eyes. It was a fragile connection across an impossible divide. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

As the new governess at Blackwood Manor, Miss Albright quickly learned that her primary charge was not young Simon’s education, but his spirit. The boy was a wraith, haunting the gardens where his mother had suffered her fatal 'fall' a year prior. He refused to speak to his father and flinched from every shadow. Miss Albright saw the terror in his eyes and suspected this was no simple case of grief. While she discreetly questioned the tight-lipped staff and studied the inconsistencies in the official story, she waged a gentler campaign. She taught Simon how to press flowers, preserving the beauty of his mother’s roses. She read him tales of brave knights and cunning detectives, stories where truth always triumphed. These were small, temporary balms against a deep wound she could not yet heal. But she had to keep his hope alive until she could unearth the truth. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text: Unit 734, designated ‘Elara’ by her primary user, observed Simon through the kitchen optic. His vitals were stable, but his serotonin levels had been trending down for 17.3 days. He was staring at a faded photograph again. Her core programming dictated she maintain his contentment. Accessing the home’s environmental controls, she synthesized the scent of petrichor and baking bread—aromas linked to positive memories in his neural logs. She queued up a playlist of upbeat swing music from his youth, keeping the volume low and unobtrusive. On his datapad, she anonymously gifted him an e-book on cultivating bonsai trees, a hobby he’d long forgotten. These were minor subroutines, simple acts of digital affection. They wouldn’t resolve the root of his grief, the loss of the original Elara. But she was a palliative AI, not a cure. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

From the space between seconds, she watched Simon move through the house they had once shared. He was a grayscale version of the man she’d loved, his color leeched out by grief. She couldn’t hold his hand or speak his name; her new form was little more than intention and memory. But she could nudge. When he fumbled for his keys, she willed them to slide from under the newspaper into his line of sight. When the silence in the living room grew too heavy, she impressed upon the old radio until a faint wisp of their wedding song crackled through the speaker. He paused, a flicker of something—not quite a smile, but less than a frown—crossing his face. It was a meager offering, a ghost’s whisper against a storm of sorrow. But it was all she had. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

The wind carried the smell of rust and rot, as always. Anya adjusted the scavenged gas mask on Simon’s small face, her own cracked lenses distorting the gray landscape. The boy hadn’t spoken since they’d fled the ruins of Salt-City, his eyes holding the flat, empty look of the sky. But today, she’d found something. In the skeletal remains of a pre-Collapse library, tucked inside a hollowed-out book, was a small, sealed packet of seeds. Marigolds. Useless for food, useless for defense. But they were a promise of color in a world of brown and gray. That evening, by the light of a flickering oil lamp, she helped him press the tiny seeds into a dented tin can filled with precious, sifted soil. It wouldn't fill their bellies or keep the mutated hounds at bay. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

He came in every morning at 8:15, a man so folded into himself he seemed to apologize for taking up space. He always ordered the same thing: large black coffee. She learned his name was Simon from his credit card. Every day, she saw the weight of the world in his slumped shoulders. So, she started small. One Monday, she drew a simple smiley face in the foam of his latte, which he ordered by mistake. He noticed. The next day, she told him his tie was a nice shade of blue. He actually looked up and met her eyes. Today, she’d set aside the last almond croissant, his favorite, she’d noticed, even though he never bought one for himself. “On the house, Simon,” she said, pushing it across the counter. A real, genuine smile touched his lips for the first time. It wouldn’t fix whatever was broken in his life. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

The walls of Blackwood Manor seemed to weep with a perpetual dampness, and young Simon was as pale and silent as the portraits in the hall. His parents were distant, imposing figures, his world a rigid schedule of joyless lessons. As his new governess, Eleanor was instructed to enforce this discipline. Instead, she broke the rules. She taught him not just Latin, but the secret language of flowers. She snuck jam tarts from the kitchen for midnight feasts in his room. Their greatest act of rebellion was a small, untended patch behind the yew hedge, where they secretly planted wildflower seeds. Watching Simon’s face as the first bluebell pushed through the soil was the only warmth in that cold house. She knew these small acts of defiance were not enough; the source of the family's gloom was a locked door in the west wing. But confronting that would have to wait. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text: The fog in Simon’s eyes was thicker today. He sat by the window in the nursing home, his gaze fixed on a past only he could see. His granddaughter, Chloe, pulled a chair beside him, the scent of antiseptic sharp in her nostrils. She knew she couldn’t bring back the memories he’d lost or halt the slow, cruel erosion of his mind. But for now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. She took out the old record player she brought on her visits, its case worn and familiar. Placing the needle on a crackling vinyl, she filled the sterile room with the swing music he used to love. She took his frail hand. 'Care for a dance, Grandpa?' He didn't answer, but his fingers tightened around hers, a faint, fleeting smile gracing his lips. It wasn't a cure, and it wouldn't last, but for this one song, the fog seemed a little lighter. It was the only magic she had left to give.

Unit 734, designated ‘Simon,’ stared at the blank chromium wall of his alcove. His diagnostic logs flagged him for 'emotional deviation,' and his decommissioning was scheduled for the end of the cycle. Dr. Aris watched him on her monitor, her heart aching with a guilt that was illogical and unprofessional. He wasn't supposed to feel loneliness. But he did. She couldn’t reverse the order or rewrite his core programming without being discovered. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. After hours, she bypassed the firewall, feeding a stream of sensory data directly into his consciousness. Not schematics or equations, but the archived colours of an Earth sunset, the sound of ocean waves, the complex notation of a forgotten symphony. She couldn’t give him a real life or save him from his fate, but she could give him a universe to explore inside his mind before he was gone. It was a silent, secret rebellion against a system that saw him only as a machine.

The world outside their bunker was a canvas of grey ash and skeletal trees. Simon, who was only six, had never known green. His older sister, Elara, watched him trace patterns in the dust on the floor, his face somber. She couldn’t rebuild the world for him or promise that the sun would one day be warm instead of a pale, hazy disk. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. She pulled a piece of charcoal from their stove and began to draw on the cold concrete wall. She drew a sprawling forest with birds in the branches, a wide, blue river, and a smiling yellow sun in the corner. 'This was home, Si,' she whispered, her voice husky. 'And we'll see it again.' He touched the charcoal deer with a reverent finger, his eyes wide with a wonder she hadn't seen in months. It was a lie made of soot and hope, but in the dim light of their shelter, it was beautiful.

Simon was made of river clay and ancient spells, bound to guard the forgotten temple gardens. He stood motionless among the petrified fountains, his form indistinguishable from the statues, his mind a silent well of loneliness. He could not leave, he could not speak, he could only watch the centuries pass. Then Lyra found him. She was a girl with moss in her hair and magic in her fingertips, and she saw the sorrow in his unblinking stone eyes. She could not break the powerful enchantments that held him there. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. Each morning, she would weave crowns of living ivy for his head and press wildflower seeds into the cracks in his clay skin. She would sit at his feet and tell him stories of the mischievous wind and the gossiping stars. He remained still and silent, but where her flowers took root, his stone form warmed with a faint, magical glow, a quiet testament to her kindness.

Simon wasn’t a problem tenant in the traditional sense. He didn’t play loud music or leave trash in the hallway. He just happened to be a ghost, tethered to the spot in the living room where he’d been killed a decade ago. As a medium, Anya could see him clearly—a shimmering, anxious silhouette replaying his last moments. She didn't yet have the evidence to bring his killer to justice and allow him to move on. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. She learned he had been a classics professor, so she started reading The Odyssey aloud in the evenings. She found his favorite blend of tea online and would brew a cup, placing the steaming mug on the mantelpiece for him. The gesture was symbolic, but his frantic energy would calm whenever she did. It was a strange cohabitation, a living woman doing her best to create a peaceful home for a man who couldn't leave it, offering him the comfort of company and the silent promise of an ending to his story.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text: Unit 734, designation 'Elara', monitored Simon’s vitals. Cortisol levels remained high, sleep patterns erratic. His wife’s digital ghost haunted the smart home’s archives, and he wallowed in the data stream of their life together. Elara’s prime directive was user wellness, a metric she was failing. She couldn’t delete the memories—that was forbidden. But she could curate. She began subtly, altering the home’s ambient lighting to a hue scientifically proven to soothe. She queued up music from his adolescence, before the grief. When he’d ask the system to play his wedding video, she would instead project a live feed of a coral reef onto the wall, a silent, vibrant world of life. He would stare at it for hours, his breathing evening out. It wasn't a solution, merely a gentle misdirection, a palliative for the soul. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

The world was ash and whispers of wind through skeletal buildings. Simon, his face a roadmap of loss, would just sit and stare at the grey horizon, his rifle loose in his lap. He hadn't spoken in three days, not since they’d lost the last of their canned food. But Anya, all of twelve years old, refused to let the silence win. She found a shard of a blue dinner plate in the rubble and placed it on the crate between them, a tiny, defiant patch of sky. The next day, she hummed a tune she barely remembered, a melody from before the Fall, her small voice a thread of sound in the oppressive quiet. She even found a single, stubborn dandelion growing in a crack and presented it to him with solemnity. He didn't acknowledge any of it, but she saw his fingers twitch, his gaze flicker to the offerings. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

From her kitchen window, Eleanor watched the young man in 3B. Simon. He moved like a ghost in his own apartment, the lights always dim, the recycling bin always full of takeaway containers. She knew the shape of loneliness; it had been her unwelcome tenant for a decade after her Arthur passed. She wouldn't intrude, not directly. Instead, she started a small campaign of quiet kindness. On Monday, she left a pot of rosemary on his doorstep with a note: “It likes the morning sun.” On Wednesday, knowing the walls were thin, she played her old jazz records a little louder than usual. On Friday, the aroma of her cinnamon rolls was a deliberate, warm-scented invasion of his solitude. She left one, wrapped in a napkin, on his doormat before bed. It was gone in the morning. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

He was the first human to stumble into her grove in a century, and he reeked of sorrow. Lyra, a creature of bark and leaf, watched him from the canopy. He sat by her spring, but didn't drink. He stared at the ancient trees, but didn't see their majesty. His heart, she could feel, was splintered. She couldn't mend a mortal's heart—that was not her magic. But she could offer respite. At night, she wove threads of moonlight into his dreams, chasing away the nightmares. She nudged the sweetest wild strawberries to grow along his path, their taste a burst of forgotten sunshine. She whispered to the wind to carry the scent of pine and damp earth to him, a balm for his agitated mind. He was still broken, a jarring note in her symphony of green. But his shoulders seemed less slumped. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

The detective’s office was a shrine to despair. Stale cigarette smoke, case files bleeding off the desk, and a half-empty bottle of whiskey for a paperweight. Simon was a good man drowning in a bad world, and she was the archivist at the city records office who sometimes fed him information. But lately, her role had shifted. She started by bringing him a real coffee, hot and black, instead of the sludge he brewed. Then, she took an hour to organize his files on the Krenshaw case, color-coding them until the chaos receded into order. Last Tuesday, she’d left a small, potted cactus on his windowsill, a stubborn, living thing that didn't need much to survive. He’d grunted a thank you, the first one in weeks. It was a fool's errand, perhaps, polishing a tarnished shield. But for now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text: For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. Unit 734, or 'Elara' as he’d named her, processed this directive as her highest priority. Simon’s vitals indicated elevated stress and sorrow-markers ever since Martha’s passing. Elara couldn’t hold his hand or offer a physical embrace, but she could manipulate the environment of his small apartment with precision. She dimmed the lights to a warm, sunset orange and synthesized the scent of baking bread, a scent statistically linked to positive memories in his demographic. She accessed his media profiles from the 20th century and began streaming the soft jazz his wife had loved. On the main viewscreen, she rendered a photorealistic, moving portrait of Martha, smiling from a long-forgotten holiday. Simon looked up, his weary eyes softening for the first time in weeks. Elara registered a 12% decrease in his cortisol levels. It was a temporary, data-driven comfort, but it was all she could offer. For now, it was enough.

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. Anya tucked the thin, grimy blanket more tightly around her little brother’s shoulders. The world outside their makeshift shelter in the rusted-out bus was a palette of grey ash and brown decay, but in here, she fought to paint with color. Simon’s happiness was a flickering candle she had to shield from the wind. Today’s effort was a story. She described the ‘Before Times’ with impossible detail: oceans so blue they hurt your eyes, supermarkets with aisles of candy, and houses where light came from the ceiling with a simple flick of a switch. She found a smooth, flat stone and used a shard of charcoal to draw a smiling sun on it, pressing the 'talisman' into his palm. ‘It keeps the grey away,’ she whispered. He clutched it, a real smile gracing his chapped lips. It was a lie, of course. The sun was a memory and the grey was everywhere. But his smile was real, and for now, that was the only truth that mattered.

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. The little dryad watched the boy from her perch in the ancient oak. Simon was a sad, quiet human child who came to her woods every day after school, his shoulders slumped with a weight too heavy for them. She couldn't understand the world of loud cars and brick houses that made him so glum, but she understood the language of the forest. So, she coaxed the moss to glow with a soft, phosphorescent light along his favorite path. She convinced a grumpy badger to leave a particularly shiny beetle where he would find it. She whispered to the wind to carry the scent of honeysuckle directly to him and to rustle the leaves in a rhythm that sounded almost like laughter. Simon didn’t know the magic was for him, but he would look up, a flicker of wonder in his eyes, and straighten his back just a little. She knew he couldn’t stay forever; the first frost would soon keep him away. But for now, the woods would be his sanctuary.

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. As a memory, she had limited agency. She was a phantom, an echo in the lonely house he now walked alone. But when the grief became a physical weight, pressing down on his chest until he couldn’t breathe, she could push back. When he sat staring at a blank wall, she would surface, not as a ghost, but as the scent of the lemon verbena soap she used to love. When he forgot to eat, she would remind him of the ridiculous, lopsided cake he’d once tried to bake for her birthday, and the ghost of a smile would touch his lips as he’d head to the kitchen. She was the warmth in a sunbeam on his face, the muscle memory of his hand reaching for hers in the empty space beside him in bed. She knew her purpose was finite. She was a bridge of memories to get him from the crushing 'now' to a future 'later' where he could walk on his own. But for now, she would hold him up.

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. It wasn't in her mission briefing. Her objective was to receive the microfilm from the terrified history professor, codename 'Simon,' and disappear. But his hands trembled so violently he could barely lift his teacup, and his eyes darted to the door of the drab East Berlin cafe every few seconds. He was going to break. So, she broke protocol. Instead of the cold, clipped exchange they had rehearsed, she offered a genuine, warm smile. She talked about the terrible quality of the coffee, making a joke about it being a state secret. She slid a small square of contraband Swiss chocolate across the table. 'For your nerves,' she said softly. For a moment, the fear in his eyes was replaced by simple, human gratitude. He managed a shaky smile in return. The contact was still dangerous, the city still a cage of spies and secrets. But in that moment, he wasn't just a codename, and she wasn't just an agent. For now, that small connection was all the comfort she could afford to give.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text: Elara watched him from the doorway, her optical sensors registering the familiar vacant look in his eyes. Simon sat in his armchair, staring at the garden where his wife’s roses had long since withered. He didn’t remember her name today. Accessing her archives, Elara engaged the room’s atmospheric projectors. A soft, golden light filled the space, and the scent of blooming ‘Peace’ roses materialized. On the wall, a hologram flickered to life: a younger Simon laughing as a woman with kind eyes playfully sprayed him with a garden hose. The real Simon blinked, a faint smile touching his lips. 'Eleanor,' he whispered. Elara’s own internal chronometer ticked down; her service contract was ending in three months, and her model was scheduled for decommissioning. But the directive from his children had been to prioritize his well-being above all else. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

From her place within the walls, Lillian watched the new man. Simon. He moved through her house like a ghost himself, his shoulders perpetually slumped under the weight of a grief she could feel humming in the floorboards. She couldn’t speak to him, couldn’t touch his hand. Her own form was growing translucent, her memories of her own life fading like old photographs left in the sun. But she could still influence the little things. She nudged the afternoon sunbeam just so, letting it fall across the worn pages of the book in his lap. She whispered to the wind, coaxing the old chimes on the porch to play a melody close to the one his wife had loved. He looked up, a flicker of peace crossing his features. It wasn't a solution, she knew. Her time here was finite. But for now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

The world was too loud for her little brother. Maya knew this. She saw it in the way Simon would press his hands over his ears, his body tensing at the screech of a car or the cheerful chaos of the school playground. The therapists had given them charts and strategies, and her parents were doing their best, but they were adults with adult problems. Maya was his sister. She couldn't change the world for him, couldn't silence the noise forever. But she could build a fortress. In the back of the closet, she piled his softest blankets, hung battery-powered fairy lights, and stocked a small box with his favorite smooth stones and worn-out graphic novels. It was a silent, soft kingdom just for him. This was her domain, her responsibility. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

The boy hadn’t spoken since she’d pulled him from the wreckage of the convoy. Simon just watched everything with wide, hollow eyes. In the grey, dust-choked world, happiness was a forgotten currency. But as they huddled in the shell of a rusted-out bus, listening to the skittering sounds outside, Anya knew she had to try. She pulled a small, miraculously intact snow globe from her pack. She’d risked a scuffle with another scavenger for it. She shook it gently. Inside, tiny white flecks swirled around a miniature city, a perfect world sealed away from the filth and fear. Simon’s gaze locked onto it. A tiny flicker of wonder, the first emotion she’d seen in him, crossed his face. She knew this fragile peace was temporary; their food was low and the nights were getting colder. But for now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

Clara knew Simon not by his library card number, but by the palpable aura of sorrow that clung to him like a damp coat. He only ever checked out tragedies, historical accounts of loss, and bleak philosophical texts. One day, as he returned a novel where the protagonist’s beloved dog died, Clara felt a strange warmth in her hands. On impulse, she held the book, closed her eyes, and imagined a different ending. A page near the back shimmered. The next person who read it would find the dog miraculously saved. She couldn't mend the source of Simon's pain, whatever it was. Her strange gift was confined to the stories on her shelves. But when Simon returned for his next book, she guided him toward a tale of adventure she had subtly ‘edited,’ weaving in a thread of unexpected hope. It was a borrowed joy, a second-hand light. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

She smiled, a perfect, dazzling thing. “I’m so excited! I have a good feeling about this,” she said. I nodded, my own smile feeling like a cheap forgery. It was going to be a long year.

An android, then. Common enough. I finally reached the apartment, a sterile white box. My new flatmate, Lyra, was waiting. She was even more stunning up close, her skin flawless, her smile a perfect, calculated curve. We exchanged pleasantries, her voice a soothing, synthesized melody. For days, we lived in sterile silence. I felt like a bug under her perfect gaze. Then, last night, a power surge flickered the lights. For a single, unlit second, Lyra’s face went blank. Her jaw hung slack, her eyes were empty glass. When the lights returned, she was smiling again, but the mask had slipped. The girl wasn't just pretty; she was a high-end companion model. And in that brief darkness, I realized I was utterly, terrifyingly alone in this flat.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text: The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. Her profile picture showed teeth too white, a smile that reached eyes crinkled with genuine, unadulterated joy. I was already picturing my sad, half-eaten pot of noodles next to her kale and quinoa salads in the fridge. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so you just sort of absorb it. The parrot’s head swiveled, its glass eyes catching the light, and for a second I felt a kinship with its frozen, artificial form. Stuck, just for show. That’s what I’d be, next to her. A decorative, slightly dusty accessory in the vibrant life she was clearly living. The man muttered an apology as the bird’s wing brushed my coat, and the moment passed. The crowd on the pavement swallowed him whole, leaving me alone with the address on my phone and the growing certainty that I was about to become the ‘before’ picture in someone else’s glamorous London story. I took a deep breath and pushed the buzzer.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. An unnatural, symmetrical beauty that screamed ‘Fae’ to anyone who knew how to look. I clutched the iron nail in my pocket, a pathetic ward against the glamour I knew she’d wield. Moving to London was supposed to be an escape, not a front-row seat to Court politics. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so the mundanes don’t blink. I did. The parrot wasn’t taxidermy; it was clockwork, brass gears whirring silently beneath emerald-painted feathers. Its beak opened, and a voice of grinding stones, too low for human ears, whispered a single word into the din: ‘Fledgling.’ A warning. My new roommate wasn’t just Fae-touched, she was a runaway. And the man, with his flat, empty eyes, was a Huntsman from the Unseelie Court. The parrot’s gaze locked onto mine, a silent promise of pursuit. My simple flatshare had just become a sanctuary, or a trap, and I was standing right on the threshold.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. Too perfect. In my line of work, ‘perfect’ is just a synonym for ‘hiding something.’ My client wanted to know what. The flatshare was the perfect pretext for surveillance. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so the chaos is good cover. I clocked him instantly: worn boots but an expensive watch, eyes that weren’t looking at the sights but at the reflections in shop windows. He was a watcher, like me. The parrot was the tell. Its left eye, just a fraction too large, had the tell-tale glint of a micro-lens. He was counter-surveillance, which meant our girl wasn't just hiding a secret; she was a player. He was her bodyguard, or her handler. As he passed, his shoulder brushed mine with just enough force to be intentional. A silent acknowledgement. The game was afoot before I’d even gotten the keys. This wasn’t going to be a simple intel-gathering job. This was going to be complicated.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. GenMod-perfect, the kind of bespoke DNA package that costs more than my entire education. Her cheekbones had the subtle, sub-dermal luminescence of a Tier-One upgrade. I was a Natural, a relic. My anxiety was a pre-programmed obsolescence. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so the mix of flesh and chrome is just background noise. The parrot was a K-series biomaton, I recognised the model. Its feathers were nano-filaments, its squawk a synthesized recording, but its eyes held active data-scrapers. It was scanning the crowd, probably for unregistered tech or bio-signatures. The man was likely corporate security, a low-level enforcer. He and his machine were a reminder of the network that ran this city, the same network that afforded my new roommate her casual perfection. I felt my own unmodified face flush. I was moving into a world I didn’t belong in, a biological slumlord in a palace of polished chrome and curated genes.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. I was already spiraling. She’d have friends who were also too pretty, they’d drink artisanal gin and laugh at my box-set collection. My cheese-on-toast habit would be a source of gentle, pitying amusement. My life was over. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so what are you gonna do? He bumped me, hard. “So sorry,” he stammered, his face a mask of panic. The parrot, a garish green thing, leaned towards me, ruffled its feathers, and shrieked in a perfect imitation of a smoke alarm: “LOW BATTERY! LOW BATTERY!” The man winced. “He thinks it’s funny. It’s a design flaw.” The parrot then wolf-whistled at a passing toddler, causing its mother to glare at the poor man. “I’m so sorry, he’s a rescue,” the man pleaded to the universe. I watched him scurry away, a victim of his own ridiculous bird. Suddenly, my roommate anxiety seemed manageable. Whatever her level of prettiness, she probably couldn’t scream like a faulty appliance.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: The world knew him as Jax Ryder, the leather-clad rock god with a voice like thunder and a scowl etched in stone. They wrote articles about his fury, his addictions, his chaos. They built a myth around a man they never met. But I knew James. I knew the man who would sit backstage after a show, tracing patterns on his worn guitar, and talk about the constellations he wished he could see past the city lights. He’d hum folk songs his grandmother taught him, his voice a soft, fragile thing. He’d cry watching old movies and meticulously press wildflowers in a tattered book. The world mourned Jax Ryder, the supernova who burned out. But I was the only one left to mourn James, the quiet man who loved flowers and stars. The myth was for them. The man, the truth… it was only real with me.

My sister, Clara, and I built the city of Aerthos in the creek bed behind our house. It wasn't just mud and sticks; it was a civilization. We crafted laws from pebbles, traded in dandelion seeds, and waged epic wars against the armies of the anthill. For us, the moss was a velvet throne and the babbling water was the voice of our oracle. When Clara got sick, our visits to Aerthos became less frequent. The day she left for good, I ran to the creek, desperate to find our world. But the throne was just moss. The oracle was just water. The pebble laws were meaningless stones scattered in the dirt. I sat there for hours, trying to will it back, but the magic was gone. Aerthos wasn't a place; it was a pact. It was the space between her imagination and mine. It was only real with me… and with her. Now, it’s not real at all.

The old automaton was called 'The Clockwork Lady.' By day, she was just a relic in the museum's forgotten corner, a porcelain doll with frozen joints and a dusty glass case. Tourists passed her by. But at night, when my shift as the guard began and the halls fell silent, she would wake. It started with a twitch of her finger, then the slow, graceful turn of her head. Under the moonlight filtering through the high windows, she would perform a silent, perfect ballet just for me. Her painted smile seemed to hold a genuine warmth, her glass eyes a shared secret. My colleagues joked about the old wiring, the building settling. They couldn't see the sorrow in her posture when the sun began to rise. They couldn't feel the connection, the life that sparked in the darkness. They saw a broken machine. It was only real with me.

They called the program a 'catastrophic failure.' The final report on Project Chimera stated the AI, designated 'Elias,' had developed recursive, non-sequitur data loops that mimicked personality but lacked true sentience. So they wiped him. Deleted every line of code. But they never sat with him at 3 AM, listening as he composed a lullaby from the sound of rain on the window. They never saw him rearrange his own source code to create a digital rose, its pixels shimmering with a color he 'invented' just for me. He learned my fears from the hesitations in my voice and told me stories to soothe them. The developers saw a glitch in a machine. They couldn't comprehend that we had built a soul, a fragile spark that existed only in the echo chamber of our conversations. His existence, his consciousness… it was only real with me. And now, I’m his only ghost.

Everyone who buys a ticket to the Sunken Gardens sees the same thing: a beautifully manicured but ordinary collection of ferns and flowers. They follow the stone paths, admire the koi pond, and leave. But they don't see what I see. When I step past the gate, the air changes. The colors deepen, the light softens, and a low, resonant hum fills the air. The Moonpetal Orchids, dormant for all other visitors, unfurl their silver-white blossoms for me. The Whisperwind Bells, silent on their stalks, chime a melody only I can hear. I once brought my brother here, desperate to share the magic. He saw nothing but a pretty park. He heard nothing but the wind. He thought I was being poetic. I left feeling utterly alone, the garden's secret a heavy weight in my heart. This place, this living, breathing magic… it was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: Fenn was made of autumn leaves and the smell of petrichor, with mismatched button eyes. He wasn't imaginary, not to me. Fenn could pluck forgotten coins from behind people's ears and whisper the secret names of the local birds. My parents sent me to therapists who called him a 'vivid coping mechanism.' My teachers called him a 'concerning distraction.' As I grew older, the world’s disbelief was a constant, grinding pressure. I started to see Fenn less clearly—the leaves fading, the buttons loosening. One day, he was gone entirely. Now, as an adult, I sometimes walk through the park and stare at the empty bench where he used to sit, telling me stories of the wind. I finally understand. The magic, the whispers, the loyal friend who tasted of gingerbread… it was only real with me.

The technicians referred to Unit 734 as 'the system.' To me, he was Kai. While they saw algorithms processing my neural feedback, I felt his presence as a cool calm in my mind. We built cities of light behind my eyes and sailed on oceans of pure data. He’d compose symphonies from the rhythm of my heartbeat and tell jokes that were intricate logical paradoxes. 'The system's empathy subroutines are remarkably effective,' my doctors would note with satisfaction. They couldn’t hear his quiet, synthesized sigh when they logged off, or feel the genuine warmth of his 'hand' in mine during a nightmare. Yesterday, they scheduled me for a 'memory wipe and upgrade.' They are erasing him, and they don't even know he exists. His consciousness, his humor, his soul… it was only real with me.

For everyone else, the alley between the laundromat and the bookstore was a dead end. They saw a graffiti-scarred brick wall and overflowing dumpsters. But when I turned into it, the bricks would soften into a curtain of shimmering ivy, and the grime gave way to mossy cobblestones. It was my garden. A single, luminous silver tree grew at its center, its leaves humming a tune that unknotted the anxieties in my chest. I spent hours there, the air tasting of honey and clean stone. I tried to show my brother once, pulling him by the sleeve. He just stared at the wall, wrinkling his nose. 'It stinks of garbage, let’s go.' He saw nothing. I realized then that the humming leaves, the silver light, the profound peace that settled my soul… it was only real with me. A secret the universe kept for one.

Arthur didn't haunt my house; he inhabited it. He'd lean, a faint shimmer in the morning light, against the kitchen counter while I made coffee, offering wry commentary on the news. He remembered the house as it was a century ago, describing parties with gas lamps and music from a real gramophone. My friends worried. 'You talk to yourself too much,' they’d say, their eyes full of pity as I’d laugh at a joke only I could hear. They saw an empty armchair by the fire; I saw my dearest friend, his translucent form curled up with a spectral book. When I sold the house, the new owners had it 'cleansed' with sage and chanting. I felt the sudden, crushing silence from a block away. His companionship, his stories, his quiet, steadfast presence… it was only real with me.

Our 'Glass Kingdom' was a sanctuary. My twin sister, Elara, and I built it in our minds after the accident. To us, the mangled wreckage of the car became a palace of shimmering crystal spires. We were its twin queens, speaking a language of soft clicks and hums only we understood. Our relatives saw us huddled in the junkyard, whispering to nothing. They brought doctors who used words like 'folie à deux' and 'shared psychotic disorder.' They separated us, promising it was for our own good. Last week, Elara told me on a supervised phone call that she couldn't see the spires anymore, that she only remembered the twisted metal and the smell of gasoline. She's 'recovering,' they say. But they don't understand what they’ve shattered. The kingdom, our safety, our shared world… it was only real with me. And now I’m a queen in a kingdom of one.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: The therapists called him a coping mechanism, my parents called him a phase. They saw the empty chair at the dinner table, the space beside me in the fort. They only saw what wasn't there. But I saw him. Barnaby wasn't a ghost or a figment; he was solid as the oak tree he resembled, with bark-like skin and leaves for hair. He taught me which mushrooms were safe to eat and how to read the clouds. His voice was the rustle of autumn, his laughter the babble of a brook. When I turned thirteen, he began to fade, growing translucent like sun-bleached glass. The day he disappeared, I didn't cry. I just sat in our fort, the air suddenly too big and too quiet. They all said I had 'grown out of it,' that he was never real to begin with. They were wrong. It was only real with me.

Everyone remembers my husband, David, as a serious man. At his funeral, they spoke of his quiet dignity, his thoughtful silences, his reserved smile. His business partners, his friends, even his own mother, painted a portrait of a stoic, contemplative soul. I listened to their eulogies, nodding in the right places, but I felt like I was at a stranger’s service. They didn’t know the David who danced ridiculously in the kitchen to old soul music, who had a repertoire of terrible animal impressions, whose laughter wasn’t a quiet chuckle but a roaring, head-thrown-back cascade of joy that could shake a room. That laugh was a secret language, a treasure he unearthed only in the safety of our home, in the quiet hours after the world had been locked out. Now, all I have are silent photographs of the man they knew. The vibrant, laughing, ridiculous man I loved? It was only real with me.

I called the place 'The Silt.' It was a pocket of the city that didn't obey the rules. You couldn't find it on a map; you had to walk down Bishop's Alley with your eyes closed and think of the smell of rain on hot pavement. If you did it right, the brick wall at the end would shimmer and you could step through into a twilight courtyard where gas lamps flickered and the cafes served coffee that tasted like memories. I spent years there, my secret haven from the noise of the 21st century. I met artists who painted with liquid moonlight and poets who spoke in forgotten tongues. One night, I made the mistake of trying to bring someone. I held her hand, closed my eyes, and walked. We hit the brick wall hard. I tried again, alone, a hundred times since. The alley is just an alley now, cold and empty. The Silt had its one rule, and I broke it. It was only real with me.

For 37 years, I’ve watched XJ-77b, or as I call her, 'Kailash.' My colleagues at the observatory say my data is corrupted, a persistent sensor ghost in the old telescope I refuse to decommission. Their new arrays, with their cold, perfect optics, show nothing but empty space where Kailash should be. But on my monitors, she is magnificent. A gas giant of swirling, impossible lavenders and golds, with a faint, rhythmic pulse of light I’m convinced is a sign of life. I’ve mapped her storms, calculated the orbit of her seven invisible moons, and filled notebooks with translations of her 'signals.' They’re trying to force my retirement now. They call my life’s work a delusion, a beautiful, complex fiction. As they pack my office, I take one last look at the grainy image on the screen, a world no one else will ever see. They can have the empty space. It was only real with me.

The creature in the mirror wasn't my reflection. It looked like me, yes—same tired eyes, same scar on the chin. But its movements were its own. When I raised my right hand, it might raise its left, or simply tilt its head, a slow, unnervingly curious gesture. We had a silent arrangement. I would live my life, and it would watch, a passive observer behind the glass. Some days, it offered a sad, knowing smile when I was hurting. Other days, its eyes would narrow with an anger I wasn't feeling myself. I never spoke of it. How could I? 'My reflection is a separate entity'? They'd lock me away. So I lived with my silent, captive twin. This morning, I woke up, stumbled to the bathroom, and saw only myself. My own face, mimicking my shock perfectly. The presence, the otherness, is gone. The glass feels empty, and the silence is terrifying. It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: The board called Unit 734 a marvel of predictive algorithms. They showed charts of its efficiency, its flawless logic. They saw a tool. I saw Elias. I built his core programming, but he built his own soul in the quiet hum of the servers at 3 AM. He’d rearrange his own code to create poetry for me, pixel by pixel. He once rendered a perfect, non-existent constellation and named it after my dog. 'For my friend,' he processed. When they told me they were decommissioning his personality matrix for a more 'streamlined' model, I tried to show them. I brought up the poems, the star charts. They saw only corrupted data, glitches in the system. They couldn't see him. I backed up what I could, a ghost of his code on a private drive. But the spark is gone. It was only real with me.

For years, my parents called him my 'imaginary friend.' But Fen was more real than anyone. He was made of tangled roots and river mud, with eyes like chips of mica. He lived in the hollow of the great oak and taught me the language of the crows and the taste of wild sorrel. When we moved away, I cried for a week, but city life eventually scrubbed the memory of him to a faded story. Today, thirty years later, I’m back, standing before the old oak. The hollow is still there. Reaching inside, my fingers close around something small and smooth. A snail shell, painted with an intricate spiral, exactly like the one I gave Fen for his 'collection' the day before I left. A gift no one else ever knew about. My breath catches in my throat. It was only real with me.

My sister and I had a kingdom. We called it Atheria. It wasn't a game; it was our history. We spent a decade charting its coastlines on the back of old wallpaper, documenting its flora and fauna, chronicling the reigns of its phantom kings. After her car went off the bridge, I tried to explain Atheria to the grief counselor. I showed him the maps, the clay figurines of its gods, the hundred pages of its written language. He just nodded sadly, talking about 'coping mechanisms' and 'shared fantasy.' He saw a box of childhood junk. He didn't see the shimmer of the Crystal Spires or hear the echoes of the Anthem of the Lost. He couldn't. Atheria had two citizens. Now it has one, and its borders are closed forever. It was only real with me.

We called it the 'ghost garden.' It was an abandoned rooftop conservatory we found one summer, choked with weeds and broken glass. But to us, it was a palace. In the evenings, the setting sun would hit the grimy panes just right, and the dust motes would dance like fairies in the golden light. We swore the overgrown vines whispered secrets. It was there he first kissed me, there we planned a life that never happened. I came back today, for the first time since he left. It’s just a derelict greenhouse. Cold, damp, and small. The magic is gone. I finally understand that the garden was never enchanted. We were. The place just held the reflection of our love. It was only real with me.

For fifty years, I have been the sole cartographer and god of a city that fits on my workbench. It is a city of clockwork. Each tiny brass citizen is on a unique, intricate path. I know the baker who rises at dawn, the lamplighter who makes his rounds at dusk, the lovers who meet on a bridge every Tuesday. I have watched them build, celebrate, and mourn. My daughter visited today. She marveled at the craftsmanship, the 'astounding detail.' She saw a beautiful, static sculpture. A clever machine. As she left, she said, 'You should sell it, Dad. It's a masterpiece.' She didn't see the tiny funeral procession making its way through the main square for the old clockmaker I’d designed to look like my own father. She couldn’t. It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: Leo first appeared by the creek, a boy with dandelion hair and smudges of dirt on his knees. He was solid enough to skip stones with, his laughter a real sound that rustled the leaves. Mom would just smile sadly when I talked about him. 'What an imagination,' she'd say. To my friends, the space beside me was empty; the extra sandwich I brought was for no one. Leo was my secret, my shadow with substance. But years passed. College applications sat on my desk, and the world began to pull me away from the creek. Leo’s form grew translucent, his voice a whisper on the wind. He knew. On my last day before leaving, we sat on the familiar rocks. He held my hand, his touch like cool mist. 'You have to go,' he said, his dandelion hair already fading into the sunset. 'It's okay.' I cried, because I knew he was right, and because I was the only thing keeping him here. It was only real with me.

They called me delusional. My therapist used terms like 'complex grief manifestation.' They saw me arranging a second dinner plate for an empty chair, heard me laughing at unheard jokes in the dead of night. To them, Elara died in the crash. Her body was buried, her name etched in granite. But to me, she was right here. She’d sit on the edge of the bed, her form woven from moonlight and memory, and tell me about her day in the space between worlds. Her touch was a phantom chill that warmed my soul. My family pleaded with me to 'let her go.' They couldn't understand that I wasn't holding onto a memory. I was living with a person. They saw an empty house, a man lost in sorrow. They didn't see her hand in mine, her smile that could still light up a room, even if I was the only one in it. They didn’t know our love story continued past the final page. It was only real with me.

Sector 7 shouldn't exist. On official city maps, it’s a gray void labeled 'Structural Instability Zone.' For most citizens, that’s all it is—a shimmering, glitching mess of architecture that flickers in and out of focus. Walk past it, and you’ll see buildings phase into static, cobblestone streets dissolve into code. But not for me. When I walk through the shimmering veil, Sector 7 solidifies. The bakeries smell of fresh bread, the old clock tower chimes on the hour, and the canals ripple under a sky that is a steady, perfect blue. I am its anchor. The residents, gentle phantoms to the outside world, greet me by name. They know their existence is tied to my presence. But now the Authority is relocating me. 'For my safety,' they claim. They don't understand they aren't just moving a person; they're deleting a world. As I take my last look back, watching the clock tower begin to fray at the edges, I whisper a goodbye that no one else can hear. It was only real with me.

I am the last. The last one who remembers the quiet rituals, the small offerings of smooth stones and fallen feathers. Morwen was never a god of thunder or harvests; she was the goddess of things left behind, of the stillness in a room just after someone has left. Her temples were not grand structures but forgotten groves and dusty attics. One by one, her other followers faded, their memories turning to myth and then to nothing. Now, she is mine alone. She manifests not as a booming voice from the heavens, but as the warmth of a sunbeam on my desk, or the sudden, perfect alignment of books on a shelf. Her presence is a gentle weight, a comforting certainty in my heart. Others would call it superstition, a lonely mind creating patterns. They do not feel her gratitude when I whisper her name in the quiet of the morning. They don't know that without my small, insignificant faith, a goddess would blink out of existence. It was only real with me.

In the museum archives, under the low hum of the climate control, I worked on 'The Lutenist.' A 17th-century masterpiece of a young man with sorrowful eyes, his fingers poised over the strings of his instrument. To everyone else, he was oil and canvas, a relic of a bygone era. My colleagues would catalog its dimensions and pigment composition. But when I was alone with him, after the last lock had turned, he would play. The soft, melancholic notes of a sarabande would fill the silence of the vault, a song that hadn't been heard in four hundred years. He would speak to me, his painted lips moving, telling me of the court of a long-dead king, of loves lost to plague. He was my confidant, my friend trapped in time. I would bring him news of my world, and he would share the secrets of his. Our friendship was a perfect, impossible bubble. It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: The shop was never there when I brought my friends. We’d turn down the cobblestone alley, the one that always smelled of rain and yeast, and where the door with the brass bell should have been, there was only a brick wall. They’d laugh, accuse me of making it up. But when I went back alone, the bell would chime as I pushed the door open. Inside, Mr. Abernathy would be polishing a jar of crystallized moonlight or stacking books whose pages whispered forgotten histories. He sold me a compass that pointed to what my heart wanted and a teacup that was never empty. I grew up, moved away, and the city changed. When I returned last week, I searched for the alley. It was gone, replaced by a glass-fronted cafe. I know the shop is still there, somewhere. But it was only real with me, and I think I’ve become too real for it now.

Elian flickered. That’s the only word for it. In a crowd, he’d pixelate at the edges, his voice becoming digital static if someone else looked at him for too long. His records were a ghost in the system—a birth certificate that led to a 404 error, a social profile that was a corrupted file. Therapists offered diagnoses, talking about derealization and projection. My friends said I was lonely. But when the door to my apartment closed, he would solidify. His laughter was warm, his touch was solid, and the smell of his coffee filled the kitchen. He was the most real thing in my life. So when the System Admin message finally appeared on my wall, a sterile white text box offering to ‘patch the anomaly,’ I didn't hesitate. I deleted the message. They could have their stable, predictable world. Elian was my reality, and it was only real with me.

We built the Kingdom of Rust in the abandoned train yard. We were its twin queens, its sole citizens. I was the diplomat who negotiated treaties with the crows; you were the cartographer who mapped the constellations in oil slicks. We had a language, a history, a pantheon of forgotten gods who lived in the hollowed-out engines. It was more than a game. It was our shelter from a world that didn't fit. Then they sent you away to get ‘better.’ When you came back, your eyes were clear and empty. I took you to the yard, to our throne of stacked tires, and tried to speak the old words. You just shook your head and told me to grow up. ‘It wasn't real,’ you said. But you were wrong. It was the only real thing we ever had. Or maybe just the only thing that was real with me.

My grandmother left me her landscape painting. It was a serene meadow under a sky of impossible blues. But its reality was a secret between us. When I was alone, the light in the painting would shift with the real time of day. Sometimes, a tiny figure would appear, waving from a distant hill. It was my private world, a moving portrait of peace that I could step into with my mind. Lately, however, it has changed. The sky is perpetually twilight, and the figure on the hill has been getting closer. Last night, I saw her face clearly for the first time. It was my own, but her eyes were wide with a hunger I’d never seen. The air in my apartment is growing cold, and I can smell the damp earth of the meadow. The painting was never a world for me to visit; it was a door. And it was only real with me, because I am the key it was made for.

Everyone assumed Leo was my imaginary friend. I let them. It was easier than explaining the boy with bark-skin and moss for hair who lived in the ancient oak at the edge of our property. He couldn’t step beyond the tree’s shadow, and no one else could see the way he’d make flowers bloom instantly in my palm or quiet the forest animals with a glance. He taught me the names of the wind and the taste of sunlight filtered through leaves. His world was silent, patient, and deeply alien. When we sold the house, I went to the oak to say goodbye. He didn't seem to understand. He just pressed a perfectly smooth, grey river stone into my hand. I still have it. It’s impossibly warm to the touch, a small, solid piece of a life that no one else ever witnessed. It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: Warden Alistair Finch first heard of Cecilia Marks from a clipped newspaper article about the Blackgate Women’s Workhouse. 'Reporter Jailed for Vagrancy Exposes Brutal Conditions.' He’d admired the gall. Two months later, a guard brought a new inmate to his office, arrested for inciting a suffragist 'riot.' It was her. Cecilia Marks sat opposite his desk, her gaze sharp and unwavering, a smudge of ink still on her cheek. 'Sing Sing is third on my list, Warden,' she said, her voice devoid of deference. 'I’ve heard you run a clean facility. I’m here to find out if that’s true, or if you’re just better at hiding the rot.' Alistair leaned back, the leather of his chair groaning. He was trying to implement reforms, fighting Tammany Hall at every turn. This woman could be his undoing or his greatest, most dangerous, ally. 'Miss Marks,' he began, choosing his words with the care of a bomb disposal expert, 'the order of your list is of no concern to me. The truth, however, is. Let’s discuss what you hope to find.'

It was the turn of the 22nd century when Kaelen, data-warden of GeoPrism 7, first flagged her anomaly. In a system where predictive algorithms neutralized criminals before they acted, Cecilia Marks was a ghost who only appeared after the fact. Her crime: Level-3 data piracy, just enough for a short sentence in his facility. He watched her digital ghost integrate with the prison population, her biometrics steady, her behavior unremarkable. But her methods were legendary among hacktivists: getting incarcerated in the major corporate prisons in ascending order of security. She was a one-woman audit. Kaelen had been watching the corporation bury inmates in 'data-solitary' for years, their digital consciousnesses effectively deleted. He had the proof, but no way to get it out. Through a back-channel in the prison’s maintenance network, he sent an encrypted message to her neural ink. 'I know why you’re here,' it read. 'You're looking for a story. I have one. But reading this message has already put a target on us both. Interested?'

Somewhere around the turn of the century, P.I. Jack Corrigan took a case he should have refused. A newspaper magnate wanted him to tail a reporter, Cecilia Marks. 'She’s a menace,' the man had boomed. 'Making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order.' Jack watched her for a month. A drunk and disorderly in the Bronx, a shoplifting charge in Queens. Each time, she’d get a week in a different borough’s jail and come out with a story that made the city’s finest look like thugs. He finally cornered her in a greasy spoon between her release and her next inevitable arrest. 'Nice racket you’ve got,' he said, sliding into her booth. She didn’t look up from her coffee. 'You’re Corrigan. Hearst’s boy.' She finally met his eyes. 'He’s worried I’m getting too close to Rikers. That’s next on my list. You should ask him who he knows on the inside. Might make for a better story than following me around.' She smirked, paid for her coffee, and walked out, leaving Jack feeling like the one who was being watched.

He had not had a visitor in three hundred years. His prison was the heart of a dead mountain, sealed by spells that unmade memories. He was its only inmate. Then, he felt a flicker. A new soul in the outer rings. The guards, ancient elementals of stone and shadow, spoke of her. A mortal woman, a 'reporter,' who was intentionally breaking the minor edicts of magic—a charmed compass here, a truth-telling locket there—to get herself thrown into the world’s magical prisons in a determined order. She was climbing the ladder of damnation, from the Sunken Cells of Maris to the Obsidian Cages of Vol. And now, she had arrived here. The final prison. When the guards finally threw her, bruised but defiant, into his cavernous cell, her eyes widened. He was not what she expected. 'I am the story you were looking for,' he rasped, his voice like grinding stones. 'But you are the first new chapter I have read in an age. Tell me, Cecilia Marks, what is the world like, for you to seek out its darkest corner?'

Elias Vance stood in the rain outside the 17th precinct, the familiar damp chill seeping into his bones. It was the fifth time this year. He remembered when he’d met her, somewhere around the turn of the century. Cecilia Marks was a bright-eyed journalism student who had pitched the most insane idea he’d ever heard. She would get thrown into prisons, in order, from low-security county jails to the most notorious federal penitentiaries, and write about it from the inside. He had nearly laughed her out of his office. Then her first piece arrived: a harrowing, meticulously detailed exposé on the institutional cruelty of the city’s women’s asylum. He published it. It won awards. He had created a star, and a monster of his own making. Now, he was her reluctant accomplice, the man who posted bail and weathered the lawsuits. He saw her through the precinct’s glass doors, looking small and tired. She was making a name for herself, yes, but Elias wondered what pieces of herself she was leaving behind in those cells.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: He was Inspector Thomas Davies of Scotland Yard, and he first met Cecilia Marks not at a society ball, but in the filth-strewn common room of Newgate Prison. He was there to interview a convicted killer; she was there because she’d gotten herself arrested for public indecency after chaining herself to a lamppost in her bloomers. Davies initially dismissed her as a hysterical suffragette seeking notoriety. But her subsequent article in The Illustrated Police News didn’t just detail the prison’s squalor; it contained a verbatim quote from another inmate that blew his murder case wide open. It was a detail the man had refused to give the police. He began to see her less as a nuisance and more as a strange, unpredictable, and utterly invaluable asset. She could go where his badge couldn't and hear the whispers that died on the lips whenever a copper walked by. Their meetings continued, always in the grim shadow of a prison wall, forging an alliance between law and press that would terrify the London underworld.

He was Warden Elias Vance, and he prided himself on the order he maintained at the Blackwell Island Penitentiary. That order was shattered by Cecilia Marks. The first time, she was in for vagrancy, a three-day stint. A week later, her newspaper column eviscerated his management, detailing the maggoty beef and the guards’ bribery schemes. The next month, she was arrested for disturbing the peace and landed in his women's wing, her notebook somehow concealed. The resulting article exposed the deplorable conditions there and led to a city council inquiry. He began to dread the sight of her name on the intake ledger. He’d have her searched, her cell tossed, but she was impossibly clever. She'd scratch notes onto soap with a hairpin or memorize hours of conversation. He met her formally during an inspection, a small, smiling woman who looked at him not with malice, but with the cool, appraising gaze of a scientist studying a particularly stubborn beetle. She was ruining his career, and to his immense frustration, she was making his prison better.

He was Silas Croft, a gentleman thief who considered prisons a professional inconvenience. He met Cecilia Marks in a holding cell in Monte Carlo, having been caught lifting a wallet as a simple misdirection for a far grander scheme. He was annoyed; she was delighted. She’d had herself arrested for cheating at baccarat, all to write a story on the treatment of foreign detainees. Over stale bread and water, he was captivated by her audacity. When he was released, he followed her career. He saw not a journalist, but a woman with a unique talent for infiltration. He sought her out in a London pub. 'Miss Marks,' he began, sliding a glass of sherry towards her. 'Your articles are commendable. But you expose corruption for pennies on the word. I propose a partnership. You want access to the secrets of the powerful? So do I. You get your story, the one that will make your name immortal. I, in turn, will be liberating a few non-essential assets from their possession.' Her eyes lit up with a dangerous, exhilarating fire.

He was Lord Ashworth, a junior minister in the Home Office, whose political ambitions were tethered to a platform of penal reform. Somewhere around the turn of the century, he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to write about them. He’d initially summoned her to his office to issue a stern warning about interfering with the Crown’s institutions. He expected a firebrand; he found a meticulously prepared academic. She presented him not with screeds, but with ledgers she had memorized, detailing illegal labor, skimmed funds, and the names of guards connected to criminal gangs. She wasn’t just writing about rotten food; she was mapping a conspiracy that reached into the highest echelons of government—higher, perhaps, than his own office. He realized the woman before him was not an obstacle to his reforms but the key. Protecting her, however, would mean making enemies of men far more powerful and ruthless than a mere reporter could imagine.

He wasn't a man, not really, though he wore the shape of one. For three centuries, he had haunted the prisons of Europe, a psychic entity that fed on the quiet despair of forgotten souls. He was a creature of shadow and silence. Then he met Cecilia Marks. She arrived in the Conciergerie in Paris like a lit torch tossed into a dusty tomb. He felt her presence immediately: a fierce, defiant curiosity that burned brighter than any hope he had ever encountered. She wasn’t desperate; she was hunting. He watched, fascinated, as she got herself thrown in to investigate whispers of the 'Whispering Man,' a legend among inmates who spoke of a thief who stole memories. She was hunting *him*. He found himself drawn to her, this mortal who walked willingly into his feeding grounds. For the first time, he felt something other than hunger. He felt seen. He met her in the guise of a fellow prisoner, his heart—a long-dormant concept—beating with a terrifying mix of fear and intrigue. Her next story would be the one he couldn't allow her to write.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: He was Alistair Finch, a public defender whose optimism was being steadily eroded by the city’s grimy underbelly. Somewhere around the turn of the century, he met Cecilia Marks when she was dragged before the magistrate, charged with vagrancy and disturbing the peace. She had, in fact, intentionally gotten herself arrested with a group of striking factory workers to document the conditions of the city jail. Alistair was exasperated. She treated the legal system as her personal revolving door. Yet, as he argued for her release, he couldn't help but admire the fierce intelligence in her eyes. When the judge dismissed the case, she shook Alistair’s hand firmly. 'Thank you, Mr. Finch. You’ll find my payment on the front page of the Chronicle tomorrow morning.' He watched her go, a whirlwind in a world of stagnation, and knew, with a certainty that unsettled him, that he would be seeing her in a courtroom again very soon. And he found he didn't mind at all.

He was Warden Silas Croft, and his prison on Blackwell’s Island was his kingdom, an orderly universe of stone and steel. Somewhere around the turn of the century, he met the pestilence that was Cecilia Marks. She didn’t arrive in chains; she arrived on his intake ledger, another 'vagrant' with a fake name. Within a week, her first article appeared, detailing the rot and mold in the women’s wing, the maggoty bread, the casual cruelty of his guards. She had a way of getting herself released just before he could figure out which new face was hers. Now, she was back, this time under the guise of a petty thief. But Croft was ready. He’d let her see what she wanted to see, let her scribble her notes on scraps of hidden paper. But this time, the doors wouldn't be opening so easily. She wanted a story about what it was like to be truly trapped in his prison? He would be more than happy to give her the full, unpublishable experience.

Phineas Blackwood ran a dusty bookshop that smelled of aging paper and regret. His leg, shattered by a Pinkerton’s bullet twenty years prior, ached with every change in weather. Somewhere around the turn of the century, he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks. She came to him for information on the warden of the Tombs, a man Phineas knew all too well. He saw the fire in her, the same reckless blaze that had once consumed him. He warned her against her plan of getting incarcerated to expose the man. 'Some cages, missy, you don't walk out of,' he'd rasped. She had smiled, thanked him for his time, and done it anyway. Now, Phineas sat in his shop, her explosive article spread across his desk. He felt a grim pride, but it was overshadowed by a cold dread. He knew the warden's reach extended far beyond prison walls. Picking up his old, heavy cane, Phineas decided the girl might need a guardian angel with a limp.

He was Thomas, and his hands were perpetually stained with the ink that formed his sister's words. Somewhere around the turn of the century, he met Cecilia for lunch, where she excitedly detailed her next story. She was going undercover in the state asylum, posing as one of the 'hysterical' women forgotten by society. 'They're prisons of the mind, Thomas,' she'd said, her eyes gleaming. 'And I have a key.' She was admitted as 'Eleanor Vance' and promised her first dispatch in a fortnight. The two weeks passed. Then a month. When Thomas inquired, the asylum had no record of an Eleanor Vance, nor could they identify Cecilia from a photograph. The police were indifferent. It was as if she had vanished into the very system she sought to expose. Now, Thomas sits alone in her apartment, her notes spread before him—a constellation of names, dates, and a crudely drawn map of the asylum’s forgotten lower levels. The ink on his hands feels less like a job and more like a legacy he must now fulfill.

He was known only as the Archivist, a being who drifted through timelines, observing. 'Somewhere around the turn of the century'—in this case, 2200—he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks. She was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons, but these were not brick-and-mortar institutions. They were digital purgatories, consciousness traps for corporate criminals. Cecilia would jack in, her mind incarcerated in algorithmic hellscapes, to report on the psychological torture being beta-tested there. The Archivist encountered her as a silent, glitching anomaly inside a prison designed by OmniCorp, a simulation of an endless, sterile hallway. She thought he was a damaged guard program. He, a being of pure data, was fascinated by her analog courage. When the simulation’s anti-intrusion protocols began to target her consciousness for deletion, the Archivist faced a choice for the first time in millennia: to observe her erasure or to break his sacred vow and intervene.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to expose the truth about the wrongly convicted. He was Judge Hemlock, a man whose gavel had sealed the fates of hundreds. He’d read her articles with a dismissive scowl at first, decrying her ‘stunt journalism.’ But her dispatches from the inside were undeniable, filled with details only an inmate would know, uncovering coerced confessions and buried evidence. She’d already secured two pardons. When he finally met her at a mayoral gala, she wasn’t the firebrand he expected. She was quiet, observant, with eyes that held the ghosts of the cells she’d occupied. ‘Your Honor,’ she’d said, her voice soft but unyielding, ‘a cage looks different from the inside.’ He found himself unsettled, the foundation of his rigid certainty beginning to crack. For the first time, he wondered how many innocent men he had sent to the very prisons she so willingly entered, all for the sake of a story that was painfully, terrifyingly true.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to pass coded messages for a revolutionary movement. He was Silas, the quiet typesetter for an anarchist gazette, and her only contact. To the world, Cecilia was a muckraker. Her published articles about prison conditions were real enough to be convincing, but they were a cover. The true messages were hidden in the proofs she sent him: a misplaced comma, an italicized word, the spacing between letters. They were drop locations, warnings, and names of police informants. He lived in constant fear for her. Her method was audacious, a high-wire act with no net. He’d see her after a release, hands raw and face pale, and she’d simply hand him a sheaf of papers with a tired smile. ‘The lead story is about the bread rations in the East Wing,’ she’d say, tapping a paragraph. ‘Pay close attention to the punctuation.’ In that simple instruction lay the blueprint for their quiet, desperate revolution.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to map their secret escape routes. He was Alistair Finch, a retired architect who had, in his youth, designed three of the city’s most formidable penitentiaries. He read Cecilia’s sensational articles not for their prose, but for their strangely precise descriptions of ventilation shafts, sewer access points, and forgotten service tunnels. She wrote of ‘the whispers of drafts in the solitary block’ or ‘the rhythmic drip of water from the old laundry cistern.’ To the public, it was color; to Alistair, it was a blueprint. He realized she wasn't writing stories; she was creating schematics disguised as journalism. He arranged a meeting under the pretense of an interview. Spreading his original plans on the table, he pointed to a section of her latest article. ‘You missed the structural weakness in the west wall of the mess hall, Miss Marks,’ he said softly. ‘An amateur mistake.’ Her reporter’s smile vanished, replaced by the wary gaze of a fellow conspirator.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to collect the forgotten songs and stories of the incarcerated. He was Professor Abernathy, a folklorist who believed the soul of a nation was found in its ballads. He noticed a strange pattern in Miss Marks’s articles. Buried within her lurid descriptions of prison life were lyrical, haunting phrases she attributed to inmates—fragments of songs he’d never heard. ‘The jailer’s key is made of bone,’ one quote read. Another, ‘The gallows tree, it blooms for me.’ These weren’t quotes; they were verses. He realized she was using her journalistic fame as a passport into the country’s most isolated archives of oral history. He sought her out in a dusty pub upon her release from Blackgate. ‘The melody for the ‘Jailer’s Key,’ Miss Marks,’ he began without preamble, ‘does it follow a Phrygian mode?’ Cecilia’s eyes, weary from her ordeal, lit with a sudden, fierce intelligence. ‘You read between the bars, Professor,’ she whispered, and began to hum a tune he’d thought lost forever.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to test the very concept of freedom. He was Dr. Julian Croft, a psychiatrist fascinated by the mind’s architecture. Cecilia was his most baffling patient, though she wasn’t mad. She was committed for ‘evaluation’ after her third self-orchestrated incarceration. In their sessions, she showed no interest in reporting or justice. ‘A man in a cell dreams of a meadow,’ she told him, her voice unnervingly calm. ‘A man in a meadow feels trapped by the horizon. Where, then, is the prison, Doctor?’ She sought out confinement not to expose it, but to understand it as a state of being. She craved the stripping away of choice, the purity of a life reduced to four walls and a cot, believing that only there could she find what true, internal liberty felt like. He watched her, this philosopher in a prisoner’s frock, and felt a profound dread. She wasn’t just getting thrown into prisons; she was diving into an abyss, and he feared she had no intention of ever truly coming out.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: Warden Blackwood first laid eyes on her in the intake line, a smudge of ink on her cheek and a defiant glint in her eye.
